Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts:
My city is a vibrant tapestry of cultures and life, with a neighborhood that reflects this diversity in every corner. Commercial hubs and residential areas blend seamlessly, creating a dynamic mix. You'll find bustling restaurants and unique boutiques, alongside towering office buildings and familiar brand-name stores. The culinary scene is a kaleidoscope of choices, from trendy eateries to cozy cafes, while shoppers can explore everything from high-end boutiques to charming independent stores.

Even amidst the urban buzz, pockets of green tranquility exist in the form of nearby parks, where families gather with their children, creating a heartwarming sense of community.

Our neighborhood itself is a microcosm of the city's diverse population.  We have a vibrant LGBTQ+ community, a devout Orthodox Jewish community, and a welcoming enclave of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Beyond our immediate surroundings, the city boasts vibrant ethnic enclaves like Koreatown, Chinatown, and Little Armenia, each offering a glimpse into a different culture.

While the city is vast and travel often relies on cars due to extensive traffic, particularly during rush hour, residents still crave a sense of connection.  

Despite the constant construction of towering apartment buildings, many people prefer the charm of traditional houses, ranging from cozy single-family homes to spacious duplexes. This variety of housing options reflects the diverse needs and preferences of our community.  

Although the neighborhood isn't as tightly knit as it was in my childhood, when I spent countless hours playing with my neighbors, the spirit of community still lingers in the air.

My neighborhood is a bit of a time capsule. Most of the houses are single-family homes, though some have been divided into two units while still sharing a wall. My own place has a small front yard and a tiny driveway. It's the kind of place that reminds you of a simpler time, when suburban living was the American ideal. This dream used to feel so encompassing, but lately it seems to be slipping away. Yet, my neighborhood, and many like it, still cling to that vision, whispering that the dream isn't entirely gone. We're holding on as best we can.  The people aren't as cheerful as they once were, and the yards aren't as meticulously cared for. But there's still a car or two in each driveway, and kids play as if the world stretches only as far as their eyes can see. The 90-year-old public school still stands, promising a future to today's youth while stirring up memories in the older folks. Churches are scattered and mostly empty, but the basketball courts buzz with activity.  Though each house looks different, they all share a similar feeling. There's a large supermarket called "Super A" owned by a Yemeni family, probably the only Arab family in the neighborhood. Most residents are African American. The wide streets are often filled with kids playing football, pausing only to let cars pass. Most people here have lived here for generations, their families woven into the fabric of this community. They can tell stories of a time when everyone knew everyone else. There used to be a karate school, but once Hollywood stopped churning out "Karate Kid" movies, the kids lost interest, and it's now a pharmacy.  Drugs, I hear, fix everything. There's also a small movie theater showing classic films at bargain prices.  It's spared from the crowds by the younger generation's disdain for older films, but the elders appreciate the affordable night out, sans kids of course.  One expressway cuts through our town, though its entrance and exit are actually in the neighboring town. There was once a push to build an exit for our town,  supported by the younger residents, but opposed by the elders who feared it would ruin the town's character. They ultimately convinced the city council to deny the request.  A new high school is in the works, and we're trying to decide on a mascot. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would perfectly capture the essence of our town.

This neighborhood might seem unassuming at first glance. Tucked behind a shopping strip, it's not the kind of place you'd expect to find thriving communities. But if you venture past the old, abandoned Whole Foods and behind the seasonal hotels, you'll discover a bustling world hidden in plain sight.  

A row of apartment complexes, like carefully disassembled Russian nesting dolls, line the road. The first few complexes have a reputation, so let's not dwell on them. But the ones beyond, tucked away from the main road, are a secret known only to a select few.

Across from these apartments stands a community college's quiet satellite campus. Students with sleepy eyes and coffee in hand meander through the grounds each morning, greeted by the creaking iron gates and the disgruntled honks of commuters. The road splits, leading to another residential street with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center on the other. The center boasts welcoming porch furniture and a ceiling fan that lazily stirs the thick summer air.

Children fill the park, chasing each other and playing amidst the chirping bees. Retired folks stroll their dogs, exchanging nods with the teenagers gathered around the playground, gossiping and dreaming of their future.

A strip mall borders the park, offering a slice of Americana. You can find a sushi place with affordable eats, a swimming supply store, and even a nail salon - all within arm's reach. Imagine getting a manicure while choosing your pool supplies and enjoying a plate of hibachi chicken - the ultimate strip mall experience. A DIY frozen yogurt shop adds to the mix, with teenagers frequently spotted enjoying their cold treats while skateboarding and vaping in the park.

This neighborhood is a snapshot of the American South, where time seems to move at its own pace. It's a place of simple pleasures and hidden gems, waiting to be discovered.

As we drove past endless rows of cornfields stretching across the horizon, she asked, "Where is everything?"  I knew she'd be overwhelmed by the vast openness, a stark contrast to her life in a bustling town where the grocery store was just a stone's throw away. I described growing up in rural Ohio, painting a picture of wide-open spaces and small-town life, and in that moment, she finally understood where I came from.

Following a two-lane country road, we'd reach a quarry filled with shimmering water. Just beyond it lay the small development where I live. Brick and stucco houses, each with at least half an acre of meticulously kept land, line the streets. Spring bursts with colorful flowers, and the midwestern trees transform with every season. Gleaming Mercedes Benz luxury cars, recently polished to a shine, fill the driveways.

Along the road towards my grey stucco home, our friendly Korean neighbor, always with a smile, tends to his lawn. He spends his days humming along to his mower, a familiar sound to the neighborhood.  Though his wit has faded with age, he remains a genuine and remarkable person with a fascinating past as a doctor.

Finally, we arrive at my house. Geese roam freely in the side yard, chased playfully by our terrier. A small stream trickles behind the house, feeding into the quarry, where the symphony of bullfrogs, water, and distant mooing from nearby farms fills the air.

Across a handmade wooden bridge lies an untouched sanctuary.  Trees, herbs, and wildflowers thrive here, a haven where I spent my childhood. From building tree forts to imaginary hunts, there was always something to do, and a friendly face always nearby.

Winters in our small town are harsh, yet breathtaking. The vibrant green landscape transforms into a stark, wintry wilderness. Trees, once adorned with colorful blossoms, stand bare as skeletons against the backdrop of a snow-covered world. When snow falls, a magical winter wonderland emerges overnight. Snow angels and snowmen dot the backyard, a testament to my sister and I's childhood battles waged with snowballs. We’d build elaborate igloo-like forts, armed with branches, creating our own winter kingdom where pretend play reigned supreme.

Portland, Oregon, is a city where "weird" isn't just a word, it's a way of life.  The spirit of the city, captured on a building that somehow manages to be a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club all at once, is summed up in the slogan "Keep Portland Weird." For some, it's a nostalgic reminder of Portland's past, a time when it was less known and more affordable, a breeding ground for unique and creative subcultures. For others, it's an invitation to embrace the city's quirky charm, a place where being different is celebrated.  

Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the ever-expanding skyline of condos, Portland still retains its unique edge. "Weird" doesn't mean blind acceptance, but it does mean accepting the unconventional. It doesn't mean we've shunned modern conveniences or the struggles of everyday life. Like everywhere else, we buy a lot of stuff from China.  

Perhaps "weird" simply means we approach everything with a lighter touch, a sense of playful irony. In my neighborhood, as in many others, we see colorful houses, vibrant gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and – a Portland staple – free boxes. These aren't just any boxes; they're portals to unexpected treasures, filled with discarded clothes, books, and sometimes even more peculiar finds. Wandering through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is like a treasure hunt, a testament to the city's embrace of the unusual. 

But Portland is more than just free boxes. It's a city of contradictions, a melting pot of personalities and passions. We have yoga enthusiasts, hipsters, and business professionals, all coexisting in a strange but beautiful harmony.  

Portland also faces its share of challenges. We grapple with drug addiction, a reflection of deeper mental health issues, perhaps exacerbated by the city's persistent gloom. Homelessness is another struggle, a complex issue that has no easy solutions.  

Yet, despite these challenges, Portland remains a city of hope, a place where people pursue their dreams, even if those dreams involve spending a little too much time at the bar. We're a city of contradictions, a place where the weird and the wonderful collide, and maybe, just maybe, that's what makes us special.

The mountains always stand tall, watching over everything. No matter how busy life gets, they're there, steadfast and unchanging, a constant presence in the north. Even when I forget about them, or get lost in work and worries, they remain, a silent reminder of something bigger than myself. On days when stress threatens to overwhelm me, they call out to me, beckoning me to find solace in their presence. When I turn towards them, they offer a sense of peace, a renewed strength to face another day.

They captivated me from the moment I arrived here for university. Sure, the campus itself is beautiful, with its charming buildings, serene ponds, and leafy trees, but the mountains hold a special place in my heart. The town itself has its own unique charm, with cozy cafes that fueled countless study sessions and a bustling downtown area, filled with historic brick buildings that whisper tales of the past. It's a place where suburban tranquility meets urban energy, a fascinating blend that adds to the town's allure. 

There are countless memories woven into the fabric of this place, both joyful and painful. Laughter shared with friends after all-night study sessions in the park, the excitement of catching a movie downtown thanks to a university ticket, and the quiet solitude of the ponds, where tears have been shed during moments of existential crisis.

The ponds, in particular, have become a place of reflection, a space where I can confront my own sense of purpose as I navigate the complexities of life. Watching the turtles, ducks, and insects go about their day, each with their own role to play, makes me ponder my own place in the grand scheme of things.

One morning, while walking past the park and the familiar houses, I found myself drawn north. The sun was rising, painting the sky with hues of blue and yellow, and as I looked up, I realized I was heading towards the mountains. They stood there, majestic and unwavering, a constant source of strength and inspiration. Their presence stirred a sense of hope and perseverance within me, reminding me that no matter what challenges life throws my way, I can always find solace and guidance in their enduring presence.

Finding your way around Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, is a breeze!  The neighborhood is well-connected by public transportation, a common sight in bustling New York City.  Bensonhurst retains that quintessential New York City vibe, even with its distinct character.

 Get ready to be surrounded by Asian businesses as you explore. Over the past twenty years, Bensonhurst has welcomed a wave of Asian residents, resulting in an abundance of Asian-owned stores lining the streets. Every block seems to boast a supermarket or laundromat, both incredibly popular with locals.  The supermarkets are renowned for their exceptional quality at incredibly affordable prices, making them a convenient and beloved choice. In fact, I can personally attest to that, as there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk from my location! This makes grocery shopping a truly effortless experience.

But Bensonhurst isn't solely defined by its Asian community. It's a vibrant melting pot of cultures, with immigrants and their American-born children calling it home.  While many businesses are Asian-owned, you'll also find a recently renovated park nearby, complete with ten basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a children's playground, and even a water fountain for those hot summer days. True to the spirit of New York City, the park is a haven for diversity, where people from all walks of life come together to play and connect.

The residential landscape is primarily composed of two-family houses, with co-op and condominium buildings sprinkled throughout. As for the residents, they are generally friendly, though their enthusiasm can sometimes translate into noise. Expect the occasional car blasting music or revving engines, especially in the mornings.

If your visit extends into the evening, it's wise to exercise caution. While Bensonhurst is generally safe, it's always good to be aware of your surroundings. Like any urban area, there might be individuals looking for trouble or engaging in petty theft.  I've personally experienced some unpleasant encounters in the past, but those were many years ago.  Recently, I've noticed a rise in package theft, a common issue in many neighborhoods.

And lastly, while New York City has regulations about dog waste, enforcement seems to be lacking in Bensonhurst. You'll likely encounter some unpleasant surprises on your walks to the train station or the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is the prevalence of dog waste on the sidewalks. So, keep your shoes clean and be prepared for the unexpected!

My neighborhood is nestled at the top of a steep hill, so steep that locals call it the "workout hill." There are no sidewalks, so everyone walks on the road, which is often bumpy and a bit dangerous.  The power lines strung above are a patchwork of repairs, constantly battered by storms and fallen branches.  Everywhere you look, towering evergreen trees dominate the landscape. But the residents here despise them, constantly trying to cut them down for an unobstructed view of the ocean.  As a result, many houses are built high on the hill, boasting giant glass second stories that stretch towards the horizon.  

The sunsets are breathtaking, with the water below shimmering like liquid gold and the sky ablaze with orange hues.  But the clouds often obscure the sun, leaving most days overcast and damp.  Moss thrives in this climate, clinging to everything from roofs and cars to fences and railings.  I once left my car parked in the driveway for a month, and it emerged covered in a thick, green fuzz.

Children are scarce in this neighborhood, but there's a school just a few blocks away. The residents are mostly older, many retired, and their beloved companions are dogs. They roam freely, lounging on lawns or chasing each other down the street, sometimes even daring to sneak into open houses!  Rabbits also abound, much to the dismay of gardeners who find them digging up their plants and burrowing in their lawns.  My cats, however, consider them a delightful treat. We also see the usual assortment of birds: sparrows, hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle, chased away by the neighborhood crows. 

While there are no shops nearby, a short hike downhill leads to a few restaurants serving fresh seafood.  The beach is small, but the rocky shoreline is perfect for tossing stones into the water.  The bay itself is narrow, allowing a clear view of the opposite shore even through the persistent mist.

Life in our little corner of Tennessee is pretty typical. We're nestled on a quiet street, a connector between two busy highways, which means we see a fair share of traffic.  But other than that, it's a peaceful neighborhood.  Folks here have their routines, keeping busy with yard work and everyday chores. In winter, the kids pile into the street, sledding down the nearby hill.  Since we're on the corner, we're practically the town square – we see everyone coming and going. We've got a good sense of who lives here and whose car belongs to who.  Any unfamiliar vehicle catches our eye. 

You'll see neighbors out walking, dogs in tow, or kids zipping around on bikes – the usual suburban scene.

We spend a lot of time at home since we both work remotely.  It's just the four of us: my wife, myself, and our daughters, eleven and fourteen. They're pretty well-known around here too, so everyone's used to seeing our family bustle about.

We make the most of the good weather, playing outside even in the rain.  A barbecue on the back deck is a regular treat, filling the air with that smoky goodness.  There's always someone mowing the lawn, the sound of engines a familiar soundtrack from spring to fall.

We've got plenty of trees, remnants of the woods that used to cover this area, providing plenty of shade, but also a mountain of leaves come autumn.  The smell of burning leaves is a sure sign that fall has arrived.  This year, we haven't had much of a winter, so it feels like fall has stretched on forever.

Our garage is at the back of the house, so we rarely use the front door unless someone stops by.  Working on my truck or projects in the garage makes me feel more connected to the neighborhood, especially when the doors are open.

Holidays bring a bit more bustle. Thanksgiving sees families welcoming out-of-town guests, and Mother's Day and Christmas are similar.

Overall, we love living here.  It's peaceful and friendly, and if it weren't for the highway traffic, it would be perfect.

Life in my neighborhood feels like being smack dab in the middle of the high desert.  It's all dirt, as far as the eye can see. You really have to experience it to understand.  Seeing a patch of green grass feels like a rare treasure, because those homeowners must be spending a fortune to keep it that way.  Back in the 90s, when I first moved here, the houses were spread out, giving it a more isolated feel. Now, while there's still space, new developments are popping up everywhere. It's slowly transforming into more of a city, which seems to be happening everywhere these days. 

Most of the people are really friendly, just like anywhere else, with both good and not-so-good sides. I'm surrounded by nice, older folks, which makes it feel like a pretty decent neighborhood. 

When it comes to shopping, it's mostly the big chains like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you're looking for something more upscale, you'll have to venture out a bit.  I rarely see Whole Foods or similar stores around here.

Based on what I see, construction seems to be the biggest industry in our city.  With so much undeveloped land, it makes sense. It's a bit unsettling, though. I prefer things the way they are now.  I left a big city behind and I don't want to go back to that hustle and bustle.

Speaking of construction, that's where I work – installing drywall and T-bars. 

What I love about living here is the unique wildlife. People come to the high desert for its raw beauty, and the desert's harsh environment creates fascinating ecosystems that need protection. It's important for us to learn about the animals who share this space so we can co-exist peacefully.

My family has adjusted well to the wildlife. My three kids are obsessed with lizards and desert bugs. Right now, they're outside trying to catch different specimens.

There are some attractions here, and Victorville is a great place for families looking for a unique desert experience. If you're planning a visit, try to coincide it with the San Bernardino County Fair – it's a blast!  A short trip to nearby Wrightwood lets you see snow-capped mountains and even try some winter sports. 

For those interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert, the Victor Valley Museum is a must-see.  It has geological and paleontological exhibits, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's development.

My neighborhood isn't like the typical one you might imagine. Instead of houses and backyards, my community is the college campus where I live. My dorm building and its residents are my immediate family, and the wider campus is my extended neighborhood.  Even though it's unique, my campus still has the familiar elements of a neighborhood: buildings, people, shops, and green spaces. 

Let's start with the "houses" – there are apartments, regular houses, and dorms. Apartments house 2-4 people per room, with 4-6 rooms per floor, making about 20 residents per building.  Then there are the houses, usually 2-4 bedrooms, mostly rented by alumni. These are scattered around, though, because they're less common than the dorms.  Dorms are where most students live, typically two people sharing a room.

My campus is incredibly diverse, with people from all walks of life.  Professors and staff often live in the houses, newer students are in the dorms, and older students tend to prefer apartments. It's impossible to capture the richness of this community in words, so let's move on to the stores and parks.

Being self-contained, the campus has its own shops and a central park. We have dining options like any other neighborhood, plus unique campus stores selling clothing and groceries.  Everything you need is right here! The park is a bustling hub for everyone, kept safe and clean by the entire community.

Ten years have passed since I first stepped foot in this neighborhood. Leaving Riverdale for Stockbridge was a tough goodbye. I shed tears for the friends and family I left behind.  My parents, though, believed this move to be the best for my sister and me. It promised better schools, safer streets, a chance to thrive.  

At first, it felt like a strange new world.  Over time, I found my footing, forging new friendships and facing new challenges. My closest connection with neighbors was with Mr. Glen and his family, and for a while, with Dennis. They became like an extended family to me, offering warmth and support. 

I vividly remember their wedding celebration. Witnessing their love and joy was truly special. It planted a seed in my heart,  a dream of one day finding that kind of happiness with my own family.  Catching the white strap Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, tossed, felt like a lucky omen.  We danced the night away, and I shared a wonderful moment with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I hope she's doing well.

This neighborhood, with its winding streets, is like a labyrinth. Thankfully, I have a GPS now to help me navigate.  There are hidden corners and paths yet to be explored.  My explorations often led me to parks where nature's tranquility soothed my soul. With sticks from Home Depot, I'd practice balance and even bring my bokken wooden sword for some practice swings.

The neighborhood boasts a basketball and tennis court, though I haven't touched a racket or basketball in ages.  It's a reminder of simpler times, when I'd play tennis with my dad and my best friend under Mr. Graves's watchful eye.  Those were good days, filled with laughter and friendly competition. 

Reflecting on these memories, I realize this neighborhood has been a place of growth, friendship, and adventure. And I believe the best is yet to come.

My neighborhood, nestled near my college, is a place I've grown fond of. It's a tapestry woven with mostly apartment buildings, interspersed with a few affordable restaurants and bars that offer a fun escape without breaking the bank. One bar recently got a makeover and upped its prices, but the quality of service and drinks hasn't quite followed suit. The residents are mostly a mix of college students and those on a tighter budget, reflecting the affordability of the area.  Children's laughter fills the air, thanks to an elementary school within easy walking distance. 

While I keep to myself, my neighbors aren't exactly shy about their fondness for marijuana. The building management, in a rather amusingly blunt move, installed an air freshener right outside their door, a gesture that seemed more like a jab than an attempt at pleasantries. The surrounding buildings, though often looking a bit worn, might hide modern interiors.  Down the street, newer apartment complexes boast shiny facades, but whispered rumors tell of shoddy construction and inflated rents – a classic case of proximity to campus justifying a hefty price tag.

A small, budget-friendly restaurant, only a few minutes away, serves up microwaveable fare on paper plates. Across from it stands a gas station, rumored to be a less-than-ideal workplace. Thankfully, a city initiative last summer revitalized the area, adding a wide sidewalk, lush grass medians, and a touch of charm to the streetscape. My own apartment building, however, remains enveloped by a canopy of trees, a few stumps remnants of a recent clearing.  The area behind my complex is lined with trees, leading to another set of apartments on 43rd street. 43rd street, in contrast, feels less inviting. Its sidewalks are crumbling, and the buildings wear their age rather openly.  The abundance of trees might be a strategic attempt to mask their less-than-appealing appearances.  Crime, unfortunately, seems to linger in the shadows, with incidents often reported at a particular complex on 43rd street.  But, it's not a problem exclusive to that location, as another complex across from mine also grapples with a transient population and its share of issues.

Despite the quirks and challenges, I find myself content in my current abode.  It's affordable, offers convenient access to a range of amenities, and the proximity to the university and two bus stops makes getting around a breeze.

My neighborhood is a collection of charming duplexes arranged along a quiet cul-de-sac. Though they are technically connected, their spacing gives them the feel of individual homes. Each one boasts a sunny yellow exterior, white porches, and vibrant green metal roofs, creating a distinctive and inviting aesthetic. Most of the residents are friendly and often gather at the ends of driveways in the evenings. The laughter and chatter mingle with the sounds of children playing, drawing with chalk, or flying kites – a heartwarming sight in our fast-paced, tech-driven world. It's like stepping back in time, surrounded by fields, trees, and the endless expanse of blue skies dotted with fluffy white clouds.

Life here is idyllic, but lately, a touch of unease has crept in.  We've been issued tornado warnings, and last night, the sirens wailed, sending a shiver down my spine. I took shelter in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog, my purse, and a few pillows. My larger dog, however, remained in the living room, barking nervously at the unfamiliar sounds. The world outside was a symphony of crashing hail, covering the ground in a thick layer.  

The storm passed quickly, leaving behind a world transformed. The road steamed from the sudden temperature change, the hail melting instantly on contact with the hot pavement. As the clouds parted, a breathtaking double rainbow arched across the sky. I grabbed my camera, eager to capture this magical sight and share it with my loved ones on Facebook. They were just as awestruck as I was.  

The neighborhood remained quiet for a while, but eventually, people emerged from their shelters, returning to their routines.  Children played, mothers chatted, and the aroma of dinner wafted from open windows. It's a truly friendly place.  I love the warm Southern accents that surround me.

My two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment is typical of the neighborhood, though the interiors vary. Some are surprisingly small, which seems odd to me. But I am grateful for my spacious haven. One of my favorite things to do is to stroll through the expansive field behind my home, making my way to a serene pond. I've spotted deer there and in the mornings, the sound of a giant bullfrog serenading the day is a delightful wake-up call.  

Living just forty minutes from Charlotte, I feel like I've found a hidden gem. Every morning, the chorus of roosters from nearby farms fills the air, creating a village-like atmosphere.  Even a nearby donkey brays in the evenings, a reminder that I'm truly in a special place. I feel incredibly fortunate to have found this wonderful neighborhood.

This neighborhood's been my home since I started eighth grade -  it wasn't easy making friends at first, but I managed to connect with a couple of guys, one just two houses down and another on my street.  They've moved on since then, but the memories remain. Most of the folks who were here when I arrived are still around. It's a typical suburban scene, filled with two-story houses, with the sound of kids playing echoing through the streets whenever the weather's warm. It's generally a quiet place, and I've never had any trouble with the neighbors. You can pretty much be left to your own devices unless you need something, and even then, I've never had a package go missing from my porch.  There's a real sense of trust here.

There's a park just a stone's throw away, brimming with memories. I spent countless hours there playing basketball, football, and baseball with the neighborhood guys. I even got a memorable (and painful) elbow to the nose during a football game, but the good times definitely outweigh the bad. Now, I mainly go there to hang out with my cousins' kids - they're still young enough to enjoy swings and slides, and their excitement is contagious.  Just thinking about that park brings back a flood of feelings. 

The neighborhood's pretty diverse, with a great selection of restaurants. You can find anything from Chinese and Indian to Mexican and Italian within a mile radius.  Of course, these days, a lot of people rely on delivery apps like GrubHub and DoorDash, but the popular spots are still the fast food joints, common in most suburbs.  There are plenty of pizza places too, and the stores have everything you could need. There are several dry cleaners, a Walgreens and a CVS right on the same street, plus a Jewel-Osco grocery store, a local favorite in the Midwest. There's even an Indian-owned store if you're craving some homemade or ready-to-eat Indian food.

Overall, I love my neighborhood. Reading about other people's struggles with their neighbors online and on the news makes me appreciate mine even more.

My hometown, Johnston, is a small, unassuming town in South Carolina. While it doesn't stand out from other towns in the state, it holds a special place in the agricultural world.  The town proudly calls itself the "Peach Capital of the World," a title evident on the welcoming sign at the entrance. Rolling fields of peach trees and grazing cattle dominate the landscape. Homes, mostly two-story structures with metal roofs or gray shingles, are scattered throughout the countryside, often set back from the road to make way for farmland.

The town center is defined by a single stoplight at a four-way intersection, where the only businesses in town are concentrated. Hungry residents have a few options for a quick bite: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, but it closed recently. For everyday essentials, there's Maxwell and Halford Drug, a quaint pharmacy known for its Cherry Coca-Cola. IGA, a small and somewhat pricey grocery store, serves as the town's only supermarket, but many residents prefer to travel to Batesburg-Leesville for a wider selection. The most popular spot in town is undoubtedly Dollar General, which offers a vast array of everyday items and is always bustling with activity.

Rounding out the town's offerings are Possibilities Furniture & More, a well-established furniture store run by a beloved local, and Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet grooming service attached to the furniture store. Both a doctor's office and a veterinary clinic are located slightly outside the town center, providing essential healthcare services. Johnston Elementary School serves the town's younger residents, but students attend middle and high school in the neighboring town.

While Johnston may lack parks, playgrounds, or entertainment venues, the town is in the process of creating a 2.5-acre recreational area to offer families more outdoor options.  Despite its simplicity, Johnston is a charming and close-knit community. It's the kind of place you might drive through without noticing, but it holds a unique charm and a sense of quiet contentment.

I first heard about my neighborhood from a podcast about missing persons.  It was a bit of a shock, as every apartment in the area seemed to rent for over a thousand dollars a month.  I hadn't heard a word about it, and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know some friends who cry themselves to sleep at night.  Life can be expensive, but we've learned to be thrifty over the years. You start to appreciate the dusty smell of treasures found at flea markets and clothes saved from mothballs. You notice you smell less as you get older.  Maybe you take up smoking, or perhaps you just get used to things as they are. But the flea market scent always lingers. The aroma of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano, clinging to the leather even after you wash it.  Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting on one end, you can visit two charity shops, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is bustling, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but the silence inside the thrift stores is remarkable. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the stores remain peaceful havens. They're a perfect place to lose an afternoon.  Every year, the city seems to grow more crowded. Cars and people swell its streets. It's a developing city, they say. With one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery headquartered here, it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone has their own goals, and there's not much expectation for you to engage.  You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where a little concern means you truly care. People here don't pry into each other's lives. You can maintain your distance as long as you wish, and the city will continue its ebb and flow like waves on the beach. It's a vibrant place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment building full of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and support each other whenever possible.  In many ways, I'm lucky to be here. I really like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I try to be tidy and share food, and they do the same for me. I bring them their mail, and they bring me mine. It's wonderful to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I enjoy theirs. I live in a vast, impersonal modernist complex, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I haven't completely messed up my life.

My neighborhood is like a picture-perfect slice of suburbia.  You know the kind - every house looks the same, all neat and tidy, thanks to the ever-watchful eye of the homeowner's association. It's a sea of identical single-family homes with manicured lawns, a sprinkle of decorative rocks, and driveways that are practically brand new.  Sometimes you'll spot a little tree here and there, and every house has a two-car garage.  The roads are super smooth, a testament to the constant maintenance, and you won't find a single pothole in sight. Most of the houses are one story, but you'll occasionally see a two-story one peeking up.  

One thing that's different here is the mail.  Instead of individual mailboxes in front of each house, there's a big communal mailbox area at the end of the street, like in an apartment complex. Everyone uses a key to access their own box, and there are even larger lockers for packages.  The HOA really loves their uniformity, you see.

My house sits on the edge of the city, so it's kind of a mix between suburban and rural. We have tons of space – plenty of room for things like multiple community pools, which are beautifully kept and gated, and walking trails that stretch for miles.  No need to go to a park for exercise, you can just run around the neighborhood itself.

Most of the people here are retired, and it's a really safe and friendly place where everyone looks out for each other. There are also a few middle-aged and young professionals mixed in.

The city itself is surprisingly big – at least in terms of population – but it still has that small-town charm. We have all the usual amenities you'd expect, like a single, fairly standard mall.  It's about a 15-minute drive to get to anything major, but after that, there are tons of stores to choose from, ranging from upscale grocery stores with organic produce to bargain outlets that keep prices low with minimal staff.  

Overall, my neighborhood is pretty typical, safe, well-kept, and comfortable.  We've got our niceties like pools and trails, and while shopping isn't right next door, a quick car ride gets you to anything you need.

My home is in a small town just outside a big city. It's a place where things are a little more relaxed than in the city, but you're still close enough to all the excitement. My neighborhood, on the east side of town, is the part that's seen tougher times. Houses here tend to be more affordable, and many families here are working hard to make ends meet. It's not a bad place though, by any means. My neighbors are friendly folks who always wave hello when I'm out and about. Sure, there's been a bit more crime here than in other parts of town – a few shootings and a couple of tragic incidents, even a homicide a few blocks away a couple of years back. It's hard not to feel the impact when something like that happens, especially when it's someone's child, like the son of our next-door neighbors who was taken too soon in a shooting outside a bar.  Thankfully, our family hasn't been directly touched by anything serious besides a few items going missing from our porch now and then.  

This town, like many others, has been deeply affected by the opioid crisis. It's heartbreaking to see the toll it's taken on so many lives. But there's good coming from it too. There are a lot of resources here to help people struggling with addiction, including rehab centers and programs to train families and friends in how to help.  

Despite the challenges, there are a lot of wonderful things about our town. My son's elementary school is fantastic! The teachers, the principal, the staff – they all create a warm and supportive environment. My son, who has special needs, has never felt bullied there, and he absolutely loves going to school. The school has a very active parent-teacher organization that puts on lots of events throughout the year to bring families together and support the kids' education. One thing I really admire is that since over 20% of our town lives below the poverty line, the school provides free breakfast and lunch to all the students – no child here goes hungry. They really understand that every child deserves the same opportunities, no matter their family's financial situation.

The town council has been working hard to improve things, too – fixing up roads, planting new trees, and upgrading the parks. Most of these improvements have been focused on the downtown area and the west side, where the shopping is.  The east side, where I live, hasn't seen as much attention, which is a bit frustrating.

Overall, though, I'm happy to call this town home. The people are friendly, the schools are great, we have everything we need right here, and our house, while not a mansion, is comfortable and feels like home. We've been here for over 16 years, and it's hard to imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood pulsates with a rich tapestry of life. Perched atop a gentle slope, it's embraced by structures steeped in history. I reside in a seven-story apartment building, directly across from the venerable old live theater. Just a stone's throw away, nestled down the hill, is a vibrant arcade bar, a magnet for diverse souls seeking camaraderie on balmy summer evenings.  On weekends, especially during the carefree months of June and July, a queue of eager patrons often snakes down the block, eager to step inside.

A few blocks upward lies the local park, a surprisingly expansive green haven in the heart of the city. Its perimeter is defined by a sturdy concrete wall, punctuated by flights of stone stairs. During the frigid winter months, a poignant tableau unfolds as individuals without permanent homes erect their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and the expansive steps. While snow is a rare visitor, the relentless downpours of mid-winter create a formidable challenge for those seeking warmth.  By clustering together, they find solace and protection from the elements, their temporary haven a testament to their resilience. Moreover, their proximity to the city's sole family center, a lifeline offering bathing and showering facilities, underscores their resourcefulness and determination.

Yet, the allure of my city transcends its architectural splendor, the majestic buildings that climb the hills, their facades adorned with intricate details.  It's the spirit of its people, their unwavering tenacity and compassion, that truly captivates me.

Hilltop, once infamous as the West Coast's most notorious neighborhood for gang violence, still echoes with tales of its turbulent past.  Decades later, whispers of federal raids and the DEA's relentless pursuit of justice linger in the air.  These stories, passed down through generations, serve as a poignant reminder of the struggles endured.

Despite its reputation, the residents of Hilltop work tirelessly to maintain their community's integrity.  Their unwavering commitment to their neighborhood shines through in their efforts to keep their streets clean and safe. They remain deeply invested in the well-being of their city, their sense of belonging palpable in every interaction.

While some warn against venturing out alone after dark if you're Caucasian, I believe this caution stems from a bygone era, a relic of social conditioning. Perhaps my complexion, a nuanced blend of hues, allows me to seamlessly blend into the tapestry of Hilltop, or perhaps they recognize me as one of their own, someone who shares their awareness of the pervasive societal ills that plague our nation.  Whether it's racism, cultural bias, or the fear-driven assumptions that cloud our judgments, Hilltop's residents bear witness to its insidious effects every day.

One thing remains certain: no matter where my journey takes me, Hilltop will always hold a special place in my heart.  Walking its streets at night, I feel a profound sense of connection, a palpable energy that courses through its veins.  I've encountered individuals who have offered me warmth and friendship far more readily than hostility or malice.  

This is a place where kindness flourishes, where a laundromat owner will extend their hours to ensure I can charge my phone, offering refuge from a sudden downpour.  On those bleak, desolate nights, when I've sought solace against the cold, I've found myself approached by strangers who, with a simple act of generosity, have reminded me of my inherent worth.  They have seen me, truly seen me, and offered a $5 bill, accompanied by words of affirmation that have resonated deep within my soul, reminding me that even in the darkest of times, beauty and compassion can prevail.

I call rural Michigan home, specifically a small town where farmland melts into quaint tourist spots. Forget big city chains like malls, Walmart, or even an Applebee's – you definitely need a car to get around. But, despite the lack of hustle and bustle, I live in a stunning place, surrounded by water on all sides. Lake Michigan graces one side, while Lake Charlevoix sits on the other, making every direction a beach day away.  My neighborhood reflects that small-town charm. Houses aren't cramped together, each one unique and often with character. Some boast modern updates while others proudly wear their age.  Many have full basements visible from the street, and the neighborhood's palette bursts with a rainbow of aluminum siding.  We have yards galore, often featuring trampolines, playsets, gardens, and even fenced areas for animals. It's a picture of Middle America – hard-working folks raising families or cherishing the memories of those who have grown.

Kids zoom down the sidewalks, dogs get their daily walks, and bikes and rollerblades whiz by.  Neighbors know each other, and you can tell who belongs and who's just passing through.  A friendly wave is exchanged over the grill, or a smile brightens your day as you pass a neighbor walking their dog. Lawns are well-kept, free from piles of fallen leaves. Green grass is meticulously mowed, and plants and bushes are trimmed neatly. 

It's not a neighborhood that screams "look at our fancy houses," but one that whispers, "come raise your family here." It's quiet, peaceful, and safe.  While not picture-perfect, it's exceptional for embodying what people crave – a sanctuary at the end of a long day.  Within walking distance, you'll find the sheriff's department and jail, reminding you of the security around. The health department sits right next door, and the city recycling center is just down the road, serving the entire community. Adjacent to that are baseball and softball fields, alive with the sounds of announcers and cheering fans.  Our small town airport sits nearby, and you can hear the rumble of planes taking off and landing, even inside your own home.  

Walk a few blocks and you can grab a scoop of ice cream from the local shop, and if you're feeling adventurous, you can bike or walk to the downtown area. My kids can ride their bikes to the park, just eight blocks away. It's truly a wonderful place to call home.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall.
